This newsletter was completed before the tragic death of Sir David Amess. Shocking, horrific, and yet wonderful to read the tributes to his decency from all sides of the political spectrum; yet another sad loss and another call for us to be better, kinder people.

I say â€˜completedâ€™ but, having realised Revue (despite being owned by twitter) doesnâ€™t pull in all my feeds, I had begin going through them and chucking in the â€˜most relevantâ€™. I think I only went back about three days and there are far more than anyone is likely to ever read!

One thing I notice is that the â€˜ethicsâ€™ section just grows and grows. Is that a â€˜passionâ€™ like systems Â¦ cybernetics Â¦ complexityâ€Šâ€”â€Šor is it just the righteous indignation that social media loves to throw at us, that is contribution to divisiveness and loss? I will have to think about that one. And find a way to make this much, much shorter.

#### [Mel Conway](https://twitter.com/conways_law/status/1448758104296939520?utm_campaign=Transduction%20-%20leading%20transformation&utm_medium=email&utm_source=Revue%20newsletter)

[**In local government world, itâ€™s easy for reforms to make things worseâ€Šâ€”â€ŠInstitute For Fiscal Studiesâ€Šâ€”â€ŠIFS**](https://ifs.org.uk/publications/15702?utm_campaign=buffer&utm_content=buffer073a9&utm_medium=social&utm_source=twitter.com) **â€Šâ€”â€Š** [**ifs.org.uk**](https://ifs.org.uk/publications/15702?utm_campaign=buffer&utm_content=buffer073a9&utm_medium=social&utm_source=twitter.com)

England may be one of the most fiscally centralised countries in the developed world, but local government still matters. English councils have budgets in excess of Â£50 billion. Not that youâ€™d know it. Our political leaders seem to forget it all too easily. Iâ€™ve read again the prime ministerâ€™s statement about reforms to social care funding. He did not even mention local councils. Yet it is they, not central government, that are responsible for providing, funding and administering most social care. Local government has also been in the front line both in the response to Covid and dealing with its sometimes extreme financial consequences. Croydon and Slough have both issued so-called section 114 notices, indicating an inability to balance their budgets and the need to suspend all non-essential services. A number of other councils with specific exposuresâ€Šâ€”â€ŠLuton because it owns the airport, Eastbourne because of its dependence on tourism and conferences, for exampleâ€Šâ€”â€Šhave had extraordinary additional support and borrowing powers grantedâ€¦

### Organisational development and transformation

[**The Integrator Burdenâ€Šâ€”â€Šby John Cutlerâ€Šâ€”â€ŠThe Beautiful Mess**](https://cutlefish.substack.com/p/tmb-4252-the-integrator-burden?utm_campaign=Transduction%20-%20leading%20transformation&utm_medium=email&utm_source=Revue%20newsletter) **â€Šâ€”â€Š** [**cutlefish.substack.com**](https://cutlefish.substack.com/p/tmb-4252-the-integrator-burden)

Does your role involve being an â€œintegratorâ€ across teams?

Supporting. Connecting. Cohering. Resolving. Balancing. Listening. Translating. Absorbing.

If so, there is a good chance you have a view of your organization that no one has (not even the CEO). You see and hear things most people donâ€™t see. You are taking on an emotional burden that most people donâ€™t take on. And you are shouldering an emotional burden that often goes unrecognized and unappreciatedâ€¦and unpaid.
